DataElement.preferredName: Patient Small Bowel Excision Anastomosis Debulking Personal Medical History Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to a patient's personal medical history of resection of the section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum with anastomosis when surgically removing as much of the tumor as possible.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Small Bowel Excision Anastomosis Debulking Personal Medical History
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a patient's personal medical history of resection of the section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum with anastomosis when surgically removing as much of the tumor as possible.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Small Bowel Excision Anastomosis Debulking Personal Medical History
Property.preferredDefinition: The portion of the digestive tube between the stomach and the cecum or beginning of the large intestine; it consists of three portions: duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. SYN intestinum tenue.:Removal or excision by surgical measures.:(an-AS-ta-MO-sis) A procedure to connect healthy sections of tubular structures in the body after the diseased portion has been surgically removed.:Surgically removing as much of the tumor as possible.:an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
A natural or surgically-induced connection between tubular structures in the body.
The surgical removal of as much of a malignant tumor as is reasonably possible. This procedure increases the effectiveness of the subsequent administration of chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
